could say we have eliminated the deep inequities

say that we have been perfect in implementing
HIV prevention, because I know that we have

not, but I do think that the arc of HIV epidemic
in America bends towards elimination, and

208.48.text:
today, more than any time in the last 30 years,
we have the tools and the knowledge to reverse

214.90.text:
what is the worst epidemic in recorded history.
Following the path laid out in the National

222.86.text:
HIV/AIDS Strategy will give us there. So this
afternoon I will briefly discuss why HIV matters,

230.83.text:
why NHAS tells us to stop doing some types

236.49.text:
Some new CDC activities, and partnerships,
and how we are using monitoring and feedback

241.26.text:
from interactions. So why does HIV in America
matter? First, HIV continues to be a major

249.93.text:
public health problem. Today, 1.2 million
people are living with HIV in the country

255.85.text:
and the number of persons living with HIV,
shown here in red has increased about 60%

260.94.text:
over the past 15 years. Each year, there are
about 50,000 new infections and about 20,000

267.08.text:
deaths among people with HIV, a net increase
of 30,000 people with HIV each year, this

272.59.text:
is good news, since it reflects improved diagnosis
and treatment. However, it presents a challenge

278.64.text:
for prevention as a stable incidence shown
in blue and yellow dots at the bottom of the

283.08.text:
graph, and effective treatment, result in
an increasing number of people with HIV who

288.51.text:
have the potential to transmit the virus.
In addition, it is not possible to understand

294.20.text:
HIV in the US without appreciating that it
is a quintessential issue of health inequity.

300.55.text:
As Dean Montgomery Rice highlighted earlier,
African-Americans are eight times more likely

304.99.text:
to have HIV, and Latinos three times more
likely to have HIV than white Americans. These

310.41.text:
disparities are highlighted among women. For
example, the number of women estimated to

314.48.text:
be diagnosed with HIV in their lifetime ranges
from 1 in 32 African-American women to 1 in

320.34.text:
526 White or Asian women. HIV prevalence is
also associated with population density, regional

327.48.text:
residence, poverty, education, employment,
and homelessness. In addition, men who have

332.36.text:
sex with men are 40 times more likely to have HIV
than other men and women. Yet, we have seen

339.77.text:
partial success. From 2002 to 2011, annual
new HIV diagnoses decreased 33%. This was

349.87.text:
not because we stopped testing people, in
fact, the proportion of persons with HIV aware

354.93.text:
of their status increased from 77% in 2002
to 87% in 2013. And from 2008 to 2010, estimated

364.16.text:
incidence decreased 15% among heterosexuals,
and 21% among African-American women and 22%

370.65.text:
among people who inject drugs, showing that
we know some of what needs to be done, and

376.50.text:
when done well we can tackle the prevention
challenge. But, 65% of new infections in the

384.15.text:
US are among MSM, and new infections increased
12% among men who have sex with men. There

389.95.text:
was a 22% increase among young MSM practitioners,
particularly among young African American

395.29.text:
gay and bi-sexual men. We will need to do
more of what works with greater reach if we

400.15.text:
are to reverse the epidemic among MSM. Mostly
because prevalence is so much higher among

406.20.text:
MSM than among heterosexuals, so the chance
of meeting a partner with HIV is 40 times

414.70.text:
greater. In this figure, I wanted to reflect
on this disparity, probably one of the greatest

419.74.text:
in public health. Ron Stalling Collings estimated
the lifetime risk of acquiring HIV among all

425.20.text:
MSM shown in the green line and black MSM
in the orange line. If current trends continue,

430.82.text:
half of today’s black MSM will have HIV
by the age of 35, and for MSM overall, half

435.97.text:
will have HIV by the age of 50. I wanted to
highlight these issues because it’s the

440.09.text:
social and economic context wonder how did
these issues because it is a social and context

441.78.text:
that turns disparities into inequities and
for many of us, it is the desire to fight

447.11.text:
for equity that has drawn us to healthcare
and public health, and the model data here

454.71.text:
presents a clarion call for rapid effort.
The first line in yellow represents the current

460.05.text:
situation in the US where the stable incidence
in 10 years, there would be 550,000 new infections.

467.43.text:
The blue line shows that if we reduce incidence
by 25% over 10 years, we would prevent 62,000

472.72.text:
infections and save the health care system
23 billion dollars, but if we meet the strategy’s

480.49.text:
25% goal over 5 years as shown in red, then
we would save over 100,000 infections and

486.29.text:
42 billion dollars. Faster action now saves
lives and resources later. So lastly, just

495.91.text:
paying attention to health equity while we
expand new interventions and programs is going

500.38.text:
to be essential, if we are to avoid exacerbating
the existing disparities. For example, despite

506.38.text:
the profound reductions in mortality provided
by highly active antiretroviral therapy when

511.77.text:
it was first introduced, over 80% decrease
for men and women among all races and ethnicities,

519.36.text:
inequities in the rate of mortality between
blacks and whites doubled between the early

524.13.text:
1990s and the mid 2000s. We should not repeat
the same mistake as we progress with new interventions

530.07.text:
and programs over the next five years. So
now why does NHAS tells us to stop doing some

536.50.text:
types of HIV prevention and start doing others?
Primarily because not all interventions are

541.69.text:
effective, and not effective interventions
are equal.

545.03.text:
At the time the first strategy we examined
our portfolio and found that although we were

550.73.text:
focusing only on funding scientifically proven
effective interventions, several were estimated

556.06.text:
to cost over 1 million dollars per infection
averted, compared with many others that were

560.31.text:
cost saving. We needed to prioritize. We wanted
to have the greatest impact by supporting

565.95.text:
the most cost effective combinations of scientifically
proven, scalable interventions, directed to

571.08.text: the right places, populations, and strategies. And this slide shows high

576.45.text:
impact prevention. For each potential intervention,
we assess its efficacy from either randomized

581.49.text:
controlled trials or structured studies, and
ideally, it’s effectiveness in uncontrolled

586.76.text: real life circumstances, which could be different.

591.69.text:
For example for condoms, the best case scenario
for efficacy is over 90% acquisition in HIV,

597.33.text:
but its user efficacy rate is about 80%. It’s
necessary to consider economics too, since

602.86.text:
we’ve limited resources, maximizing prevention,
means achieving the lowest cost per infection

607.67.text:
averted, or quality adjusted life year saved.
Along with economics we want to determine

612.33.text:
the feasibility of full-scale implementation
since interventions need to be at a sufficient

616.32.text:
scale. For example, a trial of 5, 2 hour behavioral
counseling sessions among women doubled condom

622.26.text:
use, but the target population was 7 million.
We develop epidemic models to project the

627.27.text:
impact of interventions together, for example
and implementing CDC’s testing guidelines,

631.87.text:
combined with expanding ART prevents more
infections than either along and is more cost

636.93.text:
effective, and based on all of this analysis
we prioritized the interventions that will

640.96.text:
have the greatest impact, and implement and
evaluate these programs, and then feed it

646.24.text:
back to do a better job with everything else.
To be most effective we also need to consider

652.23.text:
new science, although Doctor Eisinger will
talk more about this. I thought it was important

657.35.text:
to just highlight a few issues. For example,
ART reduces transmission of HIV by at least

664.06.text:
96%, and data presented last week from an
NIH trial shows that it benefits health regardless

670.77.text:
of CD4 count. HHS treatment guidelines just
gave treating all people with HIV an A1 recommendation.

679.30.text:
Yet, in practice, viral suppression rates
in the country are poor.

684.29.text:
Oral pre-exposure prophylaxis, taking medication
when one partner is HIV negative to avoid

690.47.text:
getting infected with the virus, reduces HIV
acquisition in heterosexuals, men who have

694.82.text:
sex with men, and people who inject drugs.
It’s over 90% effective when adherence is

698.86.text:
high, and CDC recently issued recommendations
for new HIV testing algorithms that detects

703.69.text:
infection only a few days after PCR positivity,
greatly reducing the false-negative rate,

710.58.text:
and assisting with rapid diagnosis of people
during acute infection while they’re most

713.82.text:
infectious and they can be told that they
have HIV and access treatment quickly.

716.17.text: And on the near horizon we see long

720.56.text:
acting ART for treatment and prep, and the
potential for microbicides and vaginal rings.

and mention that aligned with the fourth NHAS

first time. So, NHAS called for strategically

epidemic by providing 339 million dollars

their HIV prevalence. This changed allocations,

805.87.text:

810.95.text:
that prevent reaching a suppressed viral load
for people with HIV diagnosed by expanding

818.06.text:
and improving HIV testing and optimize linkage

for people with HIV, and we have two other

dollars over 5 years, provided directly or

839.73.text:

844.59.text:
for example, African Americans, Hispanic and
Native, MSM and Transgender persons. We support

851.39.text:
testing and improvements along the continuum

themselves, including through the use of prep.
A second way involves state and local health

reduction, and two, use of surveillance data

School of Medicine. To do better along the

917.65.text:
and clinics strive to include quality of care,

922.97.text:
of patients, even those who has fallen out

945.19.text:
a target of 90% for the proportion of people

958.61.text:
the average, and the national goal. In this

HIV in Virginia. We are also increasingly

and we’re obligated to provide it back to

use of it. So, in conclusion, the HIV burden

health disparities. Following NHAS has the

1004.98.text:
epidemic among MSM, and continue declines

we put resources matters, and it behooves

care system and new science provide the best

1022.06.text: the next five years. Thank you.

2646.19.text: In 2010, the President launched  our country’s first comprehensive National HIV/AIDS strategy.

2651.60.text: It called on the nation to work together to halt the epidemic.

2655.10.text: And it inspired a collective response to HIV.

2660.20.text: It led us to really focus on increasing the proportion of people who

2664.20.text: successfully move through the stages of the HIV care continuum.

2667.34.text: And it led us to address the intersection of HIV violence against

2670.10.text: women and girls and gender related health disparities.

2674.52.text: The strategy also called on all sectors from health and housing to justice and education.

2679.96.text: As well as the business community. Faith communities. Philanthropy.

2687.66.text: - to align and coordinate their efforts.

2690.56.text: Since its release stakeholders from every sector have used this

2694.96.text: strategy as a roadmap. Important progress

2696.96.text: has been made but still, much work is left to be done.

2701.84.text: Today it's clear that the next phase of this

2704.08.text: work will require an even sharper focus on delivering effective,

2708.68.text: evidence-based services to those who need them most.

2713.04.text: Gay and bisexual men of all races and ethnicities.

2728.28.text: To guide our efforts through the year 2020, the Office of National Aids Policy,

2732.84.text: working with federal agencies and communities from across the country has updated the strategy.

2738.50.text: The vision and goals of the original strategy remain.

2741.96.text: But the update integrates changes rooted in advances we have made and lessons we’ve learned since 2010.

2747.42.text: To move forward the update offers steps and actions to improve our collective response.

2755.86.text: Widespread HIV testing and prompt linkage to care to people who test positive.

2761.50.text: Support for people living with HIV so that

2763.24.text: they can remain in care and adhere to treatment.

2766.36.text: Universal viral suppression to all persons living with HIV and

2773.18.text: full access to comprehensive pre-exposure prophylaxis, otherwise known as PrEP.

2779.98.text: The update also include 10 indicators we will use

2783.58.text: to measure our progress toward achieving the strategy’s goals.

2786.56.text: This is a national plan, not a federal plan.

2795.16.text: This is our strategy. This is our time.

2798.50.text: Learn more, including specifics, on the action steps and indicators at AIDS.gov.
